questions.text: In the 19th century, a scientist conducted experiments to develop a vaccine against rabies. He used a weakened form of the rabies virus to inoculate animals and successfully protect them from the disease. Name the scientist who laid the foundation for modern immunology and vaccination.

A 35-year-old HIV-positive man presents with headache, fever, and altered mental status. India ink preparation of CSF shows rounded yeast cells with a clear halo. Which of the following stains can be used as a negative stain to visualize the capsule of the microorganism responsible for symptoms in this patient?

A microbiology resident is teaching medical students about Gram staining. She prepares slides with pure cultures of Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus. After completing the Gram staining procedure, which of the following observations would correctly differentiate these two organisms?

options.label: A
options.text: E. coli appears purple, S. aureus appears pink

options.label: B
options.text: E. coli appears pink, S. aureus appears purple

questions.correct_answer: B. E. coli appears pink, S. aureus appears purple

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding a light microscope?

options.label: B
options.text: The limit of resolution for a light microscope is about 0.2 μm.

options.label: C
options.text: Contrast is only achieved through staining.

questions.correct_answer: C. Contrast is only achieved through staining.
questions.explanation:
Magnification

Resolution

Contrast
  • Magnification describes the capacity to enlarge an image.
  • All microscopes employ lenses that improve magnification.
  • However, the limiting factor for distinguishing is not magnification.
  • Maximum magnification is 1000x. (Option A)
  • Resolution is the ability to distinguish two adjacent objects as distinct and separate.
  • The limit of resolution for a light microscope is nearly 0.2 μm. (Option B)
  • Two objects near less than 0.2 μm from each other cannot be resolved as distinct and separate.
  • Contrast is necessary to distinguish microorganisms from their surroundings.
  • Bright-field microscopy uses staining to visualise bacteria with a good contrasting effect.
  • Advances have been made in microscopy and new contrast methods, such as phase contrast, differential interference contrast, dark field, and fluorescence. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding an electron microscope? TEM- Transmission Electron Microscopy SEM- Scanning Electron Microscopy

options.label: A
options.text: Thick sections are to be used to study the internal structures of an organism in a TEM.

options.label: B
options.text: A fixed magnification of 1,00,000x can be obtained using an SEM.

options.label: C
options.text: The whole system of an electron microscope functions in a vacuum.

options.label: D
options.text: TEM has a resolution of 0.2 µm.

questions.correct_answer: C. The whole system of an electron microscope functions in a vacuum.
questions.explanation:
Transmission Electron Microscopy

Scanning Electron Microscopy
  • Cells and cell structures are visualised at very high magnification and resolution
  • The resolving power of a TEM is much greater than that of a light microscope. Therefore, one can view structures at the molecular level.
  • Uses a wavelength much shorter than visible light
  • The resolving power is 0.2 nm (light microscope = 0.2 µm.) (Option D ruled out)
  • As the penetrating power of an electron is very low, thin sections are needed, unless only external structures of an organism are to be studied. (Option A ruled out)
  • Sections should be stabilised and stained to be examined
  • Stains used - osmic acid, permanganate, uranium, lanthanum, or lead salts
  • Intact cells or cell components can be observed directly in the TEM by a technique called negative staining
  • Used for optimal three-dimensional examination of cells
  • Magnification ranges from as low as 15x, up to about 1,00,000x, but only the object’s surface can be visualized (Option B ruled out)
  • The specimen is coated with a thin film of a heavy metal like gold
  • Electrons are scattered from the metal coating. They are collected and projected on a monitor, producing an image
  • Large specimens can be studied with an excellent focus

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fever and an eschar on his arm after handling animal hides. Which of the following methods is used to demonstrate the capsule of the causative agent?
Which of the following receptors is primarily responsible for recognising and binding to endotoxin?

Motility

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding eukaryotic cells except?

options.label: A
options.text: Eukaryotic cells have a true nucleus, while prokaryotic cells do not.

options.label: B
options.text: Eukaryotic cells have membrane-bound organelles, whereas prokaryotic cells lack them.

options.label: C
options.text: Eukaryotic cells have linear DNA, whereas prokaryotic cells have circular DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: In eukaryotic cells, transcription and translation occur simultaneously, while in prokaryotic cells, they are separated by the nuclear membrane.

questions.correct_answer: D. In eukaryotic cells, transcription and translation occur simultaneously, while in prokaryotic cells, they are separated by the nuclear membrane.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Prokaryotic Cells

Eukaryotic Cells

Nucleus

No true nucleus, nucleoid region with circular DNA

True nucleus enclosed by a nuclear membrane

Size

Generally smaller (0.1-5.0 µm in diameter)

Generally larger (10-100 µm in diameter)

Organelles

Few organelles, no membrane-bound organelles.

Numerous membrane-bound organelles (e.g., mitochondria, ER).

Cell Wall

Present (peptidoglycan in bacteria, pseudo peptidoglycan in archaea)

Present in plants (cellulose) and fungi (chitin), absent in animals

Ribosomes

70S ribosomes

80S ribosomes in cytoplasm, 70S in mitochondria and chloroplasts

Genetic Material

Single circular DNA molecule, no histones, rarely introns present

Multiple linear chromosomes with histones, commonly introns, present

Gene Expression

Transcription and translation occur simultaneously in cytoplasm

Transcription occurs in the nucleus, translation in the cytoplasm

Reproduction

Asexual (binary fission)

Sexual and asexual (mitosis and meiosis)

Flagella

Simple, made of flagellin

Complex, 9+2 microtubule arrangement

Cytoskeleton

Absent or very simple

Complex cytoskeleton (microtubules, microfilaments)

Intracellular Movement

Generally absent

Present (vesicle transport, cytoplasmic streaming)

Plasma Membrane

No sterols (except in Mycoplasma)

Sterols (cholesterol in animals)

Protein Synthesis

Occurs in the cytoplasm

Occurs in the cytoplasm and on the rough ER

Metabolic Pathways

Various simple pathways, often anaerobic

Mostly aerobic pathways, complex metabolic processes

Examples

Bacteria, Archaea

Protists, fungi, plants, animals

questions.text: Which of the following selective media is used to isolate and differentiate Vibrio species based on their ability to ferment sucrose?

options.label: C
options.text: Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose (TCBS) Agar

questions.correct_answer: C. Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose (TCBS) Agar
questions.explanation:
Selective Media

Media

Property

   Image    

Mannitol Salt Agar (MSA)

(Option A ruled out)
  • The high salt concentration (7.5%) inhibits most bacteria, except Staphylococcus.
  • Staphylococcus aureus ferments mannitol, producing yellow colonies with a yellow zone, while other Staphylococci and Micrococcus sp. do not ferment mannitol and produce reddish colonies.

MacConkey Agar (MAC)

(Option B ruled out)
  • MacConkey Agar (MAC) consists of peptone, lactose, agar, neutral red, and taurocholate. It selectively and differentially isolates gram-negative enteric bacilli via lactose fermentation:
  • Lactose fermenters produce pink/red colonies, and
  • Non-fermenters produce colourless/transparent colonies.

Potassium Tellurite Media

(Option D ruled out)
  • Potassium tellurite media, like potassium tellurite blood agar and Tinsdale agar, selectively isolate Corynebacterium diphtheriae by inhibiting most other bacteria. C. diphtheriae reduces tellurite, forming grey to black colonies.

CLED Medium
  • A type of differential medium, akin to MacConkey agar, distinguishes between lactose fermenters (LF) and non-lactose fermenters (NLF).
  • It serves as a substitute for using both blood agar and MacConkey agar when processing urine samples.

Medium

Indicator

Colour

Mannitol Salt agar

S. aureus

Phenol red

MF (yellow)

TCBS

V. cholera

Bromothymol blue

Sucrose fermentation (yellow)

CLED

Bromothymol blue

Lactose fermentation (yellow)

Mac Conkey

Neutral red

Lactose fermentation (pink)

questions.text: Match the transport medium with the organism it is commonly used for: 1. Stuart medium a) Vibrio cholerae 2. VR medium b) Shigella, Salmonella 3. Buffered glycerol saline c) Neisseria
questions.explanation:
Organism

Transport media

Neisseria
  • Amies medium
  • Stuart's medium

Vibrio cholerae
  • VR (Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan) medium
  • Autoclaved seawater
  • Cary Blair medium

Shigella, Salmonella

  • Cary Blair medium

questions.text: In a 65 y/o male with COPD showing signs of a bacterial respiratory infection, the sputum sample undergoes culture and sensitivity testing using the Epsilometer (E-test). Following incubation, an elliptical zone of inhibition is observed around the antibiotic strip. What is the primary advantage of using the E-test in this clinical context?

options.label: A
options.text: It identifies the specific bacterium causing the infection.

options.label: B
options.text: It determines the bacterium's resistance to all known antibiotics.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows for the immediate administration of antibiotics without further testing.

questions.correct_answer: C. It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

Setup

An absorbent strip with a gradient of antibiotic concentrations is placed on a culture plate inoculated with the bacterium.

Process

The strip releases the antibiotic, creating a gradient in the medium. An elliptical zone of inhibition forms around the strip after incubation.

Determination

The MIC is identified at the point where the edge of the ellipse intersects with the strip, representing the lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits bacterial growth (MIC). (Option C)

Advantages

Allows for the simultaneous testing of multiple antibiotics on a single plate and provides a visual, precise measurement of the MIC, enhancing accuracy compared to traditional disk diffusion methods.

questions.text: A second year medical student attending his viva in the microbiology department, was asked to identify the given device and name any one item that can be sterilised by it. Which of the following options is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Hot air oven and culture media

questions.correct_answer: C. Hot air oven and glassware

questions.text: Match the following sterilisation techniques with their respective control methods. Sterilisation technique Control method 1. Hot air oven a. Bacillus pumilus 2. Autoclave b. Serratia marcescens 3. Membrane filtration c. Bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis spores 4.Ionizing Radiation d. Geobacillus stearothermophilus spores
questions.explanation:
Sterilisation technique

Control method

1. Hot air oven

c. Bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis spores

2. Autoclave

d. Geobacillus stearothermophilus spores

3. Membrane filtration

b. Serratia marcescens

4.Ionizing Radiation

a. Bacillus pumilus

questions.text: As an intern in the orthopaedic department, you have been tasked to deliver the surgical instruments planned for the operating theatre to the CSSD. What temperature settings are kept in the following sterilisation machine at the CSSD? CSSD - Central Sterile Supply Department

options.label: A
options.text: 121 o C for 15 minutes at 15 psi pressure

options.label: D
options.text: 80 o C for 20-30 minutes for 3 consecutive days

questions.correct_answer: A. 121 o C for 15 minutes at 15 psi pressure

questions.text: Which among the following is NOT true regarding Gas sterilisation?

options.label: A
options.text: Mechanism of bactericidal action is Alkylation

options.label: C
options.text: Refers to Ethylene oxide ideally used at 55-60°C for 4-12 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Suitable for fumigation of OT complexes

questions.correct_answer: D. Suitable for fumigation of OT complexes
questions.explanation:
Most commonly used
  • Ethylene oxide (ETO)

Concentration
  • 450-700 mg ETO at 55-60°C for 4-12 hours (Option C)

Mechanism of action
  • Alkylation of DNA (Option A) and associated microbial proteins

Uses
  • Cardio-pulmonary (Heart-Lung) machine (Option B), Respirators [Critical class under Spaulding’s classification]

Disadvantages
  • Irritant: workers must use protective wears while using
  • Explosive & Inflammable: Not suitable for fumigation (Option D)
